step_1.notes: The paper explicitly links Î±-synuclein (SNCA) dysfunction to Parkinson's disease (PD) pathogenesis via Lewy body formation and associates A30P with familial PD.

step_2.notes: The membrane binding assay directly evaluates SNCA function relevant to PD pathogenesis.

step_3a.notes: The study compares wild-type (Wt) and mutant SNCA (A30P) binding behaviors, fulfilling basic control requirements.

step_3c.notes: No explicit use of other clinically classified variants (e.g., P/LP or B/LB) as controls in the abstract.

step_4b.notes: Only 3 variants (A30P, A53T, E46K) are tested as controls, totaling <10.

step_1.notes: The paper links A53T to PD and examines its impact on SNCA function.

step_2.notes: Membrane binding assays are directly relevant to SNCA's role in PD.

step_3a.notes: Wild-type (Wt) and mutant SNCA (A53T) binding are compared.

step_3c.notes: No other variants are used as controls in the abstract.

step_4b.notes: Only 3 variants (A30P, A53T, E46K) are tested as controls, totaling <10.

step_1.notes: The paper associates E46K with PD and evaluates its functional impact.

step_2.notes: Membrane binding assays are relevant to SNCA's role in PD pathology.

step_3a.notes: Wild-type (Wt) and mutant SNCA (E46K) binding are compared.

step_3c.notes: No other variants are used as controls in the abstract.

step_4b.notes: Only 3 variants (A30P, A53T, E46K) are tested as controls, totaling <10.
